dt: {bc}a person devoted to intellectual, academic, or technical pursuits or interests

dt.t: This book is essential reading for every hacker, computer {wi}nerd{/wi}, systems analyst, middle manager or computer-store browser enamored of computer wizardry.

He's happy to be thought of as a {wi}nerd{/wi} with street cred. He [Neil deGrasse Tyson] shines best in impromptu settings like talk shows or needling cosmologists at the annual Asimov debates … about nothingness or alternate universes.
Will a dab of Shakespeare daintily perfume my wit or just sound like the literary belching of a compulsive {wi}nerd{/wi}?

dt: {bc}a person preoccupied with or devoted to a particular activity or field of interest

dt.t: At college she was a theater {wi}nerd{/wi}. … "I wasn't afraid to jam, with the windows down, to Phantom of the Opera," she [Kristen Bell] says.
Working beside him is his partner, Ron Johnson, another self-described snow {wi}nerd{/wi} …
[Sitcom character Steven Q.] Urkel is loaded with everything in the {wi}nerd's{/wi} bag of tics: suspenders, spectacles, squeaks, snorts, and scrawniness.

utxt.t: With his brother Hank he heads a YouTube channel with 2 million subscribers and an organization … that advances social causes and generally celebrates {wi}nerdiness{/wi}.
… a {wi}nerdish{/wi} type in one corner was madly tapping the keys of a laptop computer.
He and his two pals aren't even {wi}nerdy{/wi} enough to join the debate team or the science club, but they dote on superhero comic books.

et: perhaps from {it}nerd{/it}, a creature in the children's book {it}If I Ran the Zoo{/it} (1950) by Dr. Seuss (Theodor Geisel)
shortdef: a person devoted to intellectual, academic, or technical pursuits or interests; also : a person preoccupied with or devoted to a particular activity or field of interest
an unstylish or socially awkward person
